title: Materiales Vallejo
caption: Designing and developing a building material store’s first website.

hero.alt: Three mobile screens depicting three different sections of the Materiales Vallejo website.

subsections.text: Late January 2016 I was approached by Materiales Vallejo to design and develop their first website and was granted full creative freedom. At the time I had experience working with website builders, a grasp of basic HTML, CSS, and JavaScript, and a lot of interest to learn more about web design and development.

The project has gone through three published versions this year, each new version fixing previous errors and incorporating new design and development tools picked up along the way. The official website is in Spanish, so a separate English site was created to serve as a reference for this case study.

While the client came up with a list of products and services, I searched for website references and started exploring with layouts and site structures. I explored with different icons and imagery and drove out of town for a weekend to take product and store pictures. After a month of exploring and working on content, the client and I were happy with the proposed designs. The site had a total of 6 sections—index, products, wholesale, retail, contact, and about.

While developing the site I learned about git, HTML/CSS, SASS, and Javascript. I found it extremely challenging to learn while building. I found it frustrating that simple things took me several hours to figure out, but as the weeks went by I got better at finding answers on forums and books. The first version of the website was published mid April 2016 on AWS S3.

A month passed and I got an opportunity to critique my client’s website. I realized the site had superfluous content and numerous bugs, and as a consequence the experience was slow and fragmented. For the second version I combined the service and product sections, fixed the product navigation, and built a custom index gallery with vanilla js. The second version had a cleaner look, less text and images, and 4 sections.

image.caption: Second version of website with a unified product and service section.

subsections.text: The second version was published the last week of June, after which I continued working on client web projects. Five months passed and I got a chance to critique my client’s website again. I realized I had been designing for visuals and had no business or user problems I was trying to solve. On top of that, the website had several layout and interaction bugs that required fixing. So I decided to redesign and redevelop the website. This time, though, I defined a purpose and designed for particular business and user needs.

Materiales Vallejo is a small building material store in Matamoros, Tamaulipas selling cement, steel bars, and other building materials to local clients. The business is part of a community in Mexico where online retail is inexistent and where establishing an online presence is not even contemplated.

The website was designed to engage with local potential customers and to expedite the hiring process. Materiales Vallejo has no budget or time to manage the website. As a consequence the site was developed using Middleman, Tachyons, Gulp.js and Netlify to provide free hosting, continuous deployment, and a fast and efficient development process.

The website was designed for construction firm secretaries and small business owners that have purchasing power, are familiar with building material use and terminology, and call the business regularly to find out about product availability and pricing. Pricing is not published or displayed in the store because pricing depends on the client relationship with the business. As a consequence, each client gets a different price. While product pricing is not displayed on the website, the site was designed to ensure users always have access to the available contact form.

The business has a hiring process that requires job applicants to purchase a job application at a local supply store and deliver the form in person or via email. The website will help automate the job application process by featuring a jobs section, where potential new hires can obtain information about available jobs and fill out a form to apply online. The business will have access to the applications through Simple Form, a free service that provides a private domain to manage and store form submissions.

Core users should know who the business is and what it offers on their first impression of the website. The index page was designed to provide a quick but complete snapshot of the business and contains all the information the core user looks for. Each section was structured to provide efficient content consumption while minimizing section height to keep the experience fast.

image.alt: Mobile index page featuring a condensed and minified experience for faster content consumption.

subsections.text: Core users should be able to find available products as fast as possible. Product cards were ordered from most popular to least popular and were arranged by category. Product cards were designed to provide just enough information for users to navigate through the carrusel without having to process product details. Tapping or clicking the card reveals important purchasing details like product availability and sale unit.

image.alt: Index page featuring a continuous product swimlane.

subsections.text: Core users should be able to contact the business at any point of their experience. The site features auto-updating forms of contact that prioritize user engagement. If the business is open, contact buttons and relevant content sections invite the user to call the office. Otherwise, contact buttons and content invite the user to send an email.

image.alt: Dynamic forms of contact and text.

subsections.text: Potential applicants should be able to find details about available jobs and apply directly online by filling out an application form. The business has four different types of job positions—secretary, accountant, chofer, and assistant chofer. Job detail descriptions were prepared in advance for each position. Whenever there's an available job, changing a boolean value in Middleman will activate the job, job detail, and job application sections and create an appropriate banner on the index and about pages.

image.alt: Dynamic job banner and sample job detail and application form.
